text:
Honestly, I think it's terrible to have a workwide pileon demanding some guy gets fired because he has some idiotic beliefs that has nothing to do with his job. It has an appalling mix of mob justice, self-righteousness, totalitarianism and 10,000-against-one pileon.
Let people believe things - even insane things - right up until they try to encode those actions into policy or law.

elements.text:
Honestly, I think it's terrible to have a workwide pileon demanding some guy gets fired because he has some idiotic beliefs that has nothing to do with his job. It has an appalling mix of mob justice, self-righteousness, totalitarianism and 10,000-against-one pileon.
Let people believe things - even insane things - right up until they try to encode those actions into policy or law.

text: Then don't sign it ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

I don't exactly follow it closely, so stallman may well have done things for which I'd consider this sort of protest appropriate, however, I have certainly seen some complaints against him that have struck me as absurd and, more importantly, to <@U7HAYKY9X>’s excellent point, he doesn't have to be not-a-jackass to work with him.  Plenty of people are total assholes and also do a lot of great work.  Trying to "purge" everyone you think is a difficult personality is not only a terrible idea in practice, but in many cases reveals many of the undesirable personality traits the purgee is accused of having in the purger

’s excellent point, he doesn't have to be not-a-jackass to work with him.  Plenty of people are total assholes and also do a lot of great work.  Trying to "purge" everyone you think is a difficult personality is not only a terrible idea in practice, but in many cases reveals many of the undesirable personality traits the purgee is accused of having in the purger

text: "Undesirable personality" here is erasing his decades of sexual harassment. This is not just about beliefs, but patterns of abusive behavior spanning multiple decades, institutions and conferences that coddled his skirting basic behavior rules *specifically written to stop him* from doing so and looking the other way.

elements.text: "Undesirable personality" here is erasing his decades of sexual harassment. This is not just about beliefs, but patterns of abusive behavior spanning multiple decades, institutions and conferences that coddled his skirting basic behavior rules
specifically written to stop him
from doing so and looking the other way.

text: The list of misdemeanors on that website are all of the "wrongthink" kind: He has stupid beliefs about pedophilia, doesn't support transgender folks etc. That's their own stated motivation, and it's simply an attack on people for their societal beliefs. And not even savage beliefs, just a bit off the centrist take.

elements.text: The list of misdemeanors on that website are all of the "wrongthink" kind: He has stupid beliefs about pedophilia, doesn't support transgender folks etc. That's their own stated motivation, and it's simply an attack on people for their societal beliefs. And not even savage beliefs, just a bit off the centrist take.

text: He definitely made a friend of mine uncomfortable, trying to get her to go out with him last year (we’d met at a Meetup for developers over 50). He’d gone “incognito”, but I’d known him since I was at MIT.

elements.text: He definitely made a friend of mine uncomfortable, trying to get her to go out with him last year (we’d met at a Meetup for developers over 50). He’d gone “incognito”, but I’d known him since I was at MIT.

text: I am happy to dig up the easily googleable decades of his abusive behavior towards women and others, but its worth reflecting why some people insist on framing this as purge people for their beliegs when there's receipts going back to time immemorial.

elements.text: I am happy to dig up the easily googleable decades of his abusive behavior towards women and others, but its worth reflecting why some people insist on framing this as purge people for their beliegs when there's receipts going back to time immemorial.

text: And they link to an article where the literal #1 point of critique is "He has problematic opinions", which is followed by an article literally titled "Remove Richard Stallman and And everyone else horrible in tech". If that is not thought control and political cleansing, I don't know what is

elements.text: And they link to an article where the literal #1 point of critique is "He has problematic opinions", which is followed by an article literally titled "Remove Richard Stallman and And everyone else horrible in tech". If that is not thought control and political cleansing, I don't know what is

text: due to my ignorance on Stallman in particular I am at least open to persuasion that this sort of response to him is entirely appropriate; however in the current political climate in the US I approach the subject with enormous skepticism.  There's an awful lot of slef-righteous intolerance for diversity of opinion from people who claim to value diversity above all else, to the point where it is hardly possible to look at a news aggregator without experiencing this.  So <@U6QGE7S86> I  think that answers your question as to why some people are prickly about it.  Granted it may not be nearly the same problem outside the US, and I dearly hope it isn't

text: (and I chimed in because I have seen at least a couple of complaints against stallman which struck me as trivial and ridiculous, but I am not ruling out that he has done things that deserve to be taken far more seriously than what I am referring to)

attachments.fallback:
[March 23rd, 2021 10:13 AM] miguelraz: <@USU9FRPEU> Yeah I remember reading those threads. As I pointed above, even if that person was uncharitable, and even if we think some of those criticisms are misplaced, we should not be reinforcing pile-ons.
This can still be a great learning opportunity for a bunch of folks and I don't think are chances of making these interactions more positive is improved by how this thread is unfolding.

text: There is a huge difference when a person has power and a historical record of abusing it.

text: And besides, I think this is skirting very close to politics which has been agreed upon this slack is not the best venue for.

text: Being serious about being inclusive means acknowledging that for some people (e.g. nonbinary, LGBTQ+, underrepresented minorities), their very existence in a community is inherently a political statement, and not everyone has the privilege of living in an apolitical environment. Being serious about being respectful sometimes means it is necessary to call out people whose behavior is not. To reiterate my original sentiment, I appreciate <@U680THK2S> for making a personal statement against behavior that goes against our CoC.
